keyTakeAways: Thousands of residents in Catanduanes have evacuated due to Tropical Storm Fengshen, which is forecast to pass near the island with strong winds and coastal flooding risks.
The storm brings a 'minimal to moderate risk' of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high, prompting government-led evacuation orders.
Fengshen is part of a recurring pattern in the Philippines where cyclones frequently hit coastal regions, especially impoverished areas with limited infrastructure.
The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, with increasing storm intensity linked to climate change.
Recent disasters—including earthquakes in Cebu and the southern coast, and Typhoon Ragasa in September—have created a context of ongoing disaster strain and community vulnerability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches, thousands of residents in the Philippine island of Catanduanes have evacuated due to warnings of coastal flooding and high winds. The storm is expected to pass near the island with gusts up to 80km/h and waves up to 1.2 meters. This evacuation is part of a recurring pattern, as Catanduanes has historically been one of the first areas hit by cyclones in the western Pacific. The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms annually, and scientists link increasing storm intensity to climate change. The current crisis occurs amid a broader context of recent disasters, including deadly earthquakes in Cebu and the southern Philippines, and the previous impact of Typhoon Ragasa, showing the country's persistent vulnerability to extreme weather and seismic events.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
